subject: Re: [samuraihistory] okay, this is a stupid question - kodachi
msgSnippet: Hi the kodachi I have (Iaito) is the same length as any long wakizashi. The wood one i have is also the same length, I was pleased to find one form Japan that

Hi 

the kodachi I have (Iaito) is the same length as any
long wakizashi. The wood one i have is also the same
length, I was pleased to find one form Japan that was
the same.

I can measure the blade length if needed.

The trsuka is a standard wakizashi length handle

paul


--- Dean Wayland <dean@...>
wrote:


---------------------------------
Hi Paul,

Any idea of this kodachi's actual dimensions, blade
and grip length
etc.? 

Yours

Dean


In message
<20041003193628.84747.qmail@...>,
Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> writes
>    HI
>
>    I just recieved a pick of a kodachi that once
belonged
>    to a very famoius member of the Yagyu family
dated
>    about 1600. it has just been repolished and is
about
>    to be submitted for new papers elevating it to a
>    national treasure I will ask if I can post the
pic I
>    was sent
>
>    paul
>
>
>    --- andrea Smith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:
>
>
>    ---------------------------------
>    Ah, i'm not a member, I'm just very interested.
This
>    very interesting.
>
>    Thanks, it helps a lot!
>
>    Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:
>    HI
>
>    here is a brief description. I wont go into
details to
>    much as I assume you are not a member of either
ryu.
>
>    kukishinden Ryu (KSDR) Kodachi has only 3 kata
for the
>    use of the kodachi. Once source I know may try to
say
>    there are a further 7 ura gata for these 3 omote
gata,
>    but i have seen a Kukishin ryu densho and no ura
gata
>    were listed in it.
>
>    In each one the attacker will come at you with a
>    katana and he is trying to cut across at your
torso.
>    The reason for this is you are moving around him
and
>    you decide when to expose a weak point therefore
>    making him attack the area you choose. Once he
does in
>    all three you rush in fast and thrust the kodachi
into
>    him.
>
>    In Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu (HYR), I have not studied.
I
>    have been shown the kata once and I have them on
>    video. therefore cant describe them properly.
>
>    There are five omote kata and I am told maybe
some ura
>    gata (which I have not seen or know of). They
like the
>    Kuki kodachi involve thrusting and a few slashing
such
>    as to the neck or torso.
>
>    The HYR tend to sink lower in kamae than the
KSDR.
>
>    However there is a historical link between the
two
>    ryu.
>
>    Kukishinden Ryu is really called Kukishinden
Happo
>    Biken, and originates from Kukishin ryu (main
branch
>    of that is now Kukishinden Tenshin Hyoho) This
all
>    originates from the Kuki family who are today
still
>    soke of the tenshin hyoho branch, and also head
>    priests of the Kuki shrine. IN the 1600s Ohkuni
Onihei
>    was a shihan in the Kukishin ryu and met with
Takagi
>    Gennoshin from Takagi Yoshin ryu. together they
>    exchanged ideas etc and Takagi Yoshin ryu was
changed.
>    Kukishin ryu Bojutsu was added to Takagi. In the
early
>    1900's Ishitani (Ishiya) sensei on his death bed
>    handed menkyo kaiden makimono for the Takagi
Yoshin
>    ryu to Takamatsu Toshitsugu, they were to be
passed to
>    Kakuno one of his students. Both Kakuno and
Takamatsu
>    held menkyo Kaiden in Takagi Yoshin Ryu and
kukishin
>    Ryu. sort time later Minaki sensei is handed
menkyo
>    kaiden in the kakuno takagi ryu and from him him
the
>    HYR is developed.
>
>    for more indepth info and lines history check out
>    these sites.
>
>    http://www.hontaiyoshinryu.com/
>    http://www.hyrusa.com/index2.html
>    http://www.shinjin.co.jp/kuki/hyoho/index_e.html
>    http://kobe.cool.ne.jp/ikkansai/takagiryu.htm
>    http://www.hanako.co.uk/History.htm� (my web
site)
>
>    paul
>
>
>
>    --- andrea Smith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:
>
>
>    ---------------------------------
>    what's the difference between the Kukishinden Ryu
>    Kodachi and the Hon Tai Yoshin Ryu Kodachi? This
is
>    pretty interesting!
>
>    Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:Hi
>
>    what explaination would you like. I have studied
>    Kukishinden Ryu Kodachi and been shown Hon Tai
Yoshin
>    Ryu Kodachi.
>
>
>    Paul
>
>
>    --- andrea Smith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:
>
>
>    ---------------------------------
>    Ah, thank you. I'd like to get the explantion of
the
>    Ryu of the kodachi. *slaps self*
>
>    Richardson Paul <umaryu@...> wrote:Hi
>
>    in some cases the kodachi is also regarded as a
>    wakizashi.
>
>    Several Ryu still teach the use of the kodachi,
two I
>    can name are Kukishinden Ryu (3 kata) and HonTai
>    Yoshin Ryu (5 kata and I think some ura gata).
>
>    paul
>
>
>    --- andjoysmith <andjoysmith@...> wrote:
>
>
>    ---------------------------------
>    Okay, I know this is a very studid, but I was
>    wondering about the 
>    kodachi and what it was used for. Really help me
out.
>    What is the 
>    kodachi used for? Slap me if you like, please!
>
>
>
